docs.title: Lambda Heat Pumps Integration
docs.text: Lambda Heat Pumps is a Home Assistant custom integration for Lambda heat pumps via Modbus/TCP.

docs.title: HACS Installation
docs.text:
1. Install HACS (if not already done)
  2. Search for "Lambda heat pumps" and download the integration
  3. Restart Home Assistant
  4. Go to Settings → Devices & Services
  5. Click Add Integration and search for "Lambda Heat Pumps"

docs.title: Initial Configuration
docs.text:
When setting up the integration, you will need to provide:

  • Name: A name for your Lambda Heat Pump installation (e.g., "EU08L")
  • Host: IP address or hostname of your Lambda controller
  • Port: Modbus TCP port (default: 502)
  • Slave ID: Modbus Slave ID (default: 1)
  • Firmware Version: Select your Lambda controller's firmware version

Everything else will be configured automatically.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Full Modbus/TCP Support: Complete support for Lambda heat pumps via Modbus/TCP
  • Automatic Module Detection: Auto-detects available modules and creates appropriate entities
  • Heating Curve Configuration: Number entities for easy adjustment of heating curve support points
  • Cycling Sensors: Comprehensive cycling counters for all operating modes
  • Energy Consumption Sensors: Detailed energy tracking by operating mode
  • Room Thermostat Control: External sensor integration for precise temperature control
  • PV Surplus Control: Solar power integration for optimal energy usage

docs.title: For Users
docs.text:
• Installation Guide - How to install and set up the integration
  • Configuration - Detailed configuration options
  • Features - Overview of all available features
  • Heating Curve - Heating curve configuration guide
  • Cycling Sensors - Understanding cycling sensors
  • Energy Consumption - Energy tracking features

docs.title: Changelog
docs.text: All notable changes to the Lambda Heat Pumps integration are documented in this file.

docs.title: New Features
docs.text:
• Flow Line Offset Number Entity: Added bidirectional Modbus-synchronized Number entity for flow line offset temperature adjustment
  • Automatically created for each heating circuit (HC1, HC2, etc.)
  • Range: -10.0°C to +10.0°C with 0.1°C step size
  • Reads current value from Modbus register and writes changes directly back
  • Appears in device configuration alongside heating curve support points
  • Modbus Register: Register 50 (relative to heating circuit base address)

docs.title: Fixed
docs.text:
• Heating Curve Validation: Fixed validation logic to check both conditions independently
  • Changed elif to if to ensure both validation checks are performed
  • Now reports all validation problems when multiple heating curve values are misconfigured
  • Hot Water Temperature Limits: Adjusted minimum/maximum values for hot water to Lambda standard (25/65°C)

docs.title: Changed
docs.text: • Git Configuration: Removed automations.yaml from gitignore

docs.title: Major Changes
docs.text:
• Complete rewrite with modern Home Assistant integration framework
  • Improved entity naming and organization
  • Enhanced error handling and retry logic
  • Better Modbus communication reliability

docs.title: New Features
docs.text:
• Automatic module detection
  • Heating curve configuration
  • Room thermostat integration
  • PV surplus control
  • Comprehensive cycling sensors
  • Energy consumption tracking

docs.title: Breaking Changes
docs.text:
• Entity IDs have changed - see migration guide
  • Configuration format updated
  • Some sensor names changed

docs.title: Previous Versions
docs.text: For older changelog entries, see GitHub Releases.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: This guide helps you solve common issues with the Lambda Heat Pumps integration.

docs.title: Cannot Connect to Lambda Controller
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Integration shows "Unavailable" - Connection errors in logs

Solutions: 1. Verify IP address and port are correct 2. Check network connectivity 3. Ensure Modbus/TCP is enabled on the controller 4. Check firewall settings 5. Verify slave ID is correct

docs.title: Intermittent Connection Loss
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Entities become unavailable periodically - Connection timeouts

Solutions: 1. Check network stability 2. Increase update interval 3. Verify controller is not overloaded 4. Check for network interference

docs.title: Entities Not Appearing
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Expected entities are missing - Only some entities are created

Solutions: 1. Check firmware version setting 2. Verify module detection 3. Review integration logs 4. Restart Home Assistant

docs.title: Incorrect Values
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Sensor values seem wrong - Temperatures are off

Solutions: 1. Check register order configuration 2. Verify scaling factors 3. Check for firmware compatibility 4. Review Modbus register documentation

docs.title: Configuration Not Saving
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Changes don't persist - Options reset after restart

Solutions: 1. Check file permissions 2. Verify YAML syntax 3. Review integration options 4. Check for conflicting configurations

docs.title: Migration Errors
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Errors during version upgrade - Entities missing after update

Solutions: 1. Check migration logs 2. Verify backup before upgrade 3. Review breaking changes in changelog 4. Report issue if migration fails

docs.title: High CPU Usage
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Home Assistant becomes slow - High CPU usage

Solutions: 1. Increase update interval 2. Reduce number of entities 3. Check for error loops in logs 4. Optimize Modbus reading

docs.title: Slow Updates
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Entities update slowly - Delayed responses

Solutions: 1. Check network latency 2. Reduce update frequency 3. Optimize batch reading 4. Check controller performance

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you're still experiencing issues:

  1. Check the GitHub Issues
  2. Enable debug logging: 
    logger:
  logs:
    custom_components.lambda_heat_pumps: debug
  3. Collect relevant logs
  4. Create a detailed issue report

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text: This document describes the architecture and design of the Lambda Heat Pumps integration.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Lambda Heat Pumps integration is built on Home Assistant's modern integration framework, using:

  • Data Update Coordinator: Centralized data management
  • Platform-based Entities: Modular entity creation
  • Modbus/TCP Communication: pymodbus library
  • Configuration Flow: User-friendly setup

docs.title: Entity Platforms
docs.text:
The integration uses multiple platforms:

  • Sensor Platform: Reading sensors from Modbus
  • Climate Platform: Temperature control
  • Number Platform: Configuration entities
  • Template Sensor Platform: Calculated sensors

docs.title: Reading Data
docs.text:
1. Coordinator initiates update cycle
  2. Modbus Utils reads registers from Lambda controller
  3. Coordinator processes and caches data
  4. Entities update their state from coordinator cache

docs.title: Writing Data
docs.text:
1. Entity receives user action (e.g., set temperature)
  2. Entity validates input
  3. Modbus Utils writes to Modbus register
  4. Coordinator updates cache
  5. Entity updates state

docs.title: Coordinator Pattern
docs.text:
The LambdaDataUpdateCoordinator manages:

  • Modbus connection lifecycle
  • Data update scheduling
  • Entity state caching
  • Error handling and retries
  • Persistent data storage

docs.title: Entity Creation
docs.text:
Entities are created dynamically based on:

  • Detected hardware modules
  • Configuration options
  • Firmware version
  • User preferences

See Entity Creation Guide for details.

docs.title: Register Addressing
docs.text:
• Base Addresses: Starting addresses for each module type
  • Relative Addresses: Offsets from base addresses
  • Register Types: Holding registers, input registers

docs.title: Data Types
docs.text:
• 16-bit integers: Signed and unsigned
  • 32-bit integers: From multiple 16-bit registers
  • Floating point: Scaled integer values

See Modbus Registers Documentation for details.

docs.title: Migration System
docs.text:
The integration includes a migration system for:

  • Version upgrades
  • Breaking changes
  • Entity registry updates
  • Configuration updates

See Migration System Guide for details.

docs.title: Connection Errors
docs.text:
• Automatic retry with exponential backoff
  • Connection state tracking
  • User notifications

docs.title: Data Errors
docs.text:
• Validation of register values
  • Fallback to default values
  • Error logging

docs.title: Performance Considerations
docs.text:
• Caching: Coordinator caches all register values
  • Batch Reading: Multiple registers read in single request
  • Update Intervals: Configurable update frequency
  • Lazy Loading: Entities created only when needed

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Entity Creation
  • Modbus Registers
  • Migration System
  • Contributing Guide

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to the Lambda Heat Pumps integration!

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.11 or higher
  • Home Assistant development environment
  • Git

docs.title: Development Setup
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository
  2. Clone your fork: 
    git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/lambda_wp_hacs.git
  3. Create a virtual environment: 
    python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: .venv\Scripts\activate
  4. Install dependencies: 
    pip install -r requirements.txt
pip install -r requirements_test.txt

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text:
• Follow PEP 8 style guide
  • Use type hints
  • Write docstrings for all functions and classes
  • Keep functions focused and small

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
Write tests for new features:

async def test_new_feature():
    # Test implementation
    assert result == expected

Run tests:

pytest tests/

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Update documentation for new features
  • Add examples where appropriate
  • Keep documentation in sync with code

docs.title: Pull Request Process
docs.text:
1. Create a feature branch: 

    git checkout -b feature/my-feature

  2. Make your changes and commit: 

    git commit -m "Add new feature"

  3. Push to your fork: 

    git push origin feature/my-feature

  4. Create a Pull Request on GitHub

docs.title: PR Requirements
docs.text:
• Code follows style guidelines
  • Tests pass
  • Documentation is updated
  • Changes are backward compatible (or migration is provided)

docs.title: Reporting Issues
docs.text:
When reporting issues, please include:

  • Home Assistant version
  • Integration version
  • Error messages
  • Steps to reproduce
  • Relevant logs

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Architecture
  • Entity Creation

docs.title: Entity Creation
docs.text: This document describes how entities are created in the Lambda Heat Pumps integration.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Entities are created dynamically based on:

  • Detected hardware modules
  • Configuration options
  • Firmware version
  • User preferences

docs.title: Sensor Entities
docs.text:
Sensor entities read values from Modbus registers:

  • Temperature sensors
  • Status sensors
  • Cycling sensors
  • Energy consumption sensors

docs.title: Climate Entities
docs.text:
Climate entities provide temperature control:

  • Hot water climate
  • Heating circuit climate

docs.title: Number Entities
docs.text:
Number entities allow configuration:

  • Heating curve parameters
  • Flow line offset
  • Room thermostat parameters

docs.title: 1. Module Detection
docs.text:
The integration automatically detects available modules:

  • Heat pumps
  • Boilers
  • Buffers
  • Solar modules
  • Heating circuits

docs.title: 2. Entity Generation
docs.text:
Based on detected modules, entities are generated:

  • Sensor templates define entity structure
  • Base addresses are calculated
  • Entity names are generated

docs.title: 3. Entity Registration
docs.text:
Entities are registered with Home Assistant:

  • Unique IDs are assigned
  • Device information is set
  • Entity attributes are configured

docs.title: Legacy Names
docs.text:
Compatible with older configurations:

sensor.EU08L_hp1_temperature

docs.title: Modern Names
docs.text:
Descriptive, user-friendly names:

sensor.eu08l_heat_pump_1_temperature

docs.title: Entity Prefixes
docs.text:
Configure custom prefixes:

lambda_heat_pumps:
  name_prefix: "MyHeatPump"

docs.title: Entity Filtering
docs.text:
Filter which entities are created:

lambda_heat_pumps:
  create_entities:
    sensors: true
    climate: true
    numbers: true

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Architecture
  • Modbus Registers

docs.title: Migration System
docs.text: The Lambda Heat Pumps integration includes a migration system to handle version upgrades and breaking changes.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The migration system ensures:

  • Smooth upgrades between versions
  • Preservation of entity configurations
  • Handling of breaking changes
  • Backward compatibility

docs.title: 1. Version Detection
docs.text:
On startup, the integration checks:

  • Current integration version
  • Stored configuration version
  • Entity registry state

docs.title: 2. Migration Execution
docs.text:
If a migration is needed:

  • Migration functions are called in order
  • Configuration is updated
  • Entity registry is migrated
  • Data is preserved

docs.title: 3. Validation
docs.text:
After migration:

  • Configuration is validated
  • Entities are verified
  • Errors are logged

docs.title: Configuration Migration
docs.text:
Update configuration format:

async def migrate_config(version: str, config: dict) -> dict:
    # Update configuration structure
    return updated_config

docs.title: Entity Registry Migration
docs.text:
Update entity registry entries:

async def migrate_entities(version: str, entities: list) -> list:
    # Update entity unique IDs
    return updated_entities

docs.title: Version Numbers
docs.text:
Follow semantic versioning:

  • Major: Breaking changes
  • Minor: New features
  • Patch: Bug fixes

docs.title: Migration Mapping
docs.text:
Map versions to migration functions:

MIGRATIONS = {
    "2.0.0": migrate_to_2_0_0,
    "2.0.1": migrate_to_2_0_1,
}

docs.title: Entity ID Changes
docs.text:
When entity IDs change:

  • Old entities are removed
  • New entities are created
  • User is notified

docs.title: Configuration Changes
docs.text:
When configuration format changes:

  • Old format is converted
  • New format is validated
  • Defaults are applied

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Always test migrations
  • Provide clear migration messages
  • Preserve user data
  • Document breaking changes

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Architecture
  • Contributing Guide

docs.title: Modbus Registers
docs.text: This document describes the Modbus register structure used by the Lambda Heat Pumps integration.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The integration communicates with Lambda controllers via Modbus/TCP, reading and writing to specific registers.

docs.title: Base Addresses
docs.text:
Each module type has a base address:

  • Heat Pumps: Starting at 4000
  • Boilers: Starting at 4500
  • Buffers: Starting at 4700
  • Heating Circuits: Starting at 5000 (HC1), 5100 (HC2), etc.
  • Solar Modules: Starting at 6000

docs.title: Relative Addresses
docs.text:
Registers are addressed relative to the base address:

  • Register 0: First register of the module
  • Register 6: Operating mode (for heating circuits)
  • Register 50: Flow line offset (for heating circuits)

docs.title: Holding Registers
docs.text:
Read/write registers for configuration:

  • Temperature settings
  • Operating modes
  • Configuration parameters

docs.title: Input Registers
docs.text:
Read-only registers for status:

  • Current temperatures
  • System status
  • Sensor readings

docs.title: 16-bit Integers
docs.text:
Single register values:

  • Signed integers: -32768 to 32767
  • Unsigned integers: 0 to 65535

docs.title: 32-bit Integers
docs.text:
Two register values:

  • Low-high order
  • High-low order
  • Configurable via register_order

docs.title: Scaled Values
docs.text:
Floating point values stored as scaled integers:

  • Temperature: Register value × 0.1
  • Pressure: Register value × 0.01

docs.title: Batch Reading
docs.text:
Multiple registers read in a single request:

registers = await client.read_holding_registers(
    address=base_address,
    count=100,
    slave=slave_id
)

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
• Retry logic for connection errors
  • Validation of register values
  • Fallback to default values

docs.title: Single Register Write
docs.text:
await client.write_register(
    address=base_address + offset,
    value=scaled_value,
    slave=slave_id
)

docs.title: Multiple Register Write
docs.text:
await client.write_registers(
    address=base_address,
    values=[value1, value2, value3],
    slave=slave_id
)

docs.title: Register Documentation
docs.text: For detailed register mappings, see the Lambda Modbus documentation.

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Architecture
  • Entity Creation

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: This guide covers all configuration options available for the Lambda Heat Pumps integration.

docs.title: Initial Setup
docs.text:
When you first add the integration, you'll need to provide:

  • Name: A descriptive name for your Lambda installation
  • Host: IP address or hostname of your Lambda controller
  • Port: Modbus TCP port (default: 502)
  • Slave ID: Modbus Slave ID (default: 1)
  • Firmware Version: Your Lambda controller's firmware version

docs.title: Integration Options
docs.text:
After initial setup, you can modify additional settings:

  1. Go to Settings → Devices & Services
  2. Find your Lambda Heat Pump integration
  3. Click Configure

docs.title: Hot Water Temperature
docs.text:
• Minimum Temperature: Minimum hot water temperature (default: 25°C)
  • Maximum Temperature: Maximum hot water temperature (default: 65°C)

docs.title: Heating Circuit Temperature
docs.text:
• Minimum Temperature: Minimum heating circuit temperature
  • Maximum Temperature: Maximum heating circuit temperature
  • Temperature Step: Step size for temperature adjustments

docs.title: Room Thermostat Control
docs.text:
Enable external sensor integration for precise temperature control:

  • Room Thermostat Control: Enable/disable room thermostat integration
  • Room Temperature Offset: Offset for room temperature readings
  • Room Temperature Factor: Factor for room temperature calculations

docs.title: PV Surplus Control
docs.text:
Solar power integration for optimal energy usage:

  • PV Surplus: Enable/disable PV surplus control
  • PV Surplus Mode: Operating mode for PV surplus control

docs.title: YAML Configuration
docs.text:
For advanced users, you can configure the integration via YAML:

lambda_heat_pumps:
  name: "EU08L"
  host: "192.168.1.100"
  port: 502
  slave_id: 1
  firmware_version: "2.0"
  hot_water_min_temp: 25
  hot_water_max_temp: 65
  heating_circuit_min_temp: 20
  heating_circuit_max_temp: 60
  room_thermostat_control: true
  pv_surplus: true

docs.title: Debug Logging
docs.text:
To enable debug logging, add to your configuration.yaml:

logger:
  default: info
  logs:
    custom_components.lambda_heat_pumps: debug

docs.title: Register Order Configuration
docs.text:
For 32-bit values from multiple 16-bit registers, you can configure the register order:

lambda_heat_pumps:
  register_order: "low_high"  # or "high_low"

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Features Overview - Learn about all available features
  • Heating Curve Configuration - Configure heating curves
  • Troubleshooting - Solve configuration issues

docs.title: Cycling Sensors
docs.text: Cycling sensors track the number of operating cycles for different modes of your heat pump.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Cycling sensors count how many times your heat pump has started in different operating modes. This helps you monitor system usage and efficiency.

docs.title: Available Cycling Sensors
docs.text: For each operating mode, multiple cycling sensors are available:

docs.title: Operating Modes
docs.text:
• Heating: Cycles when heating is active
  • Hot Water: Cycles when hot water is being heated
  • Cooling: Cycles when cooling is active
  • Defrost: Cycles when defrosting is active

docs.title: Time Periods
docs.text:
For each operating mode, sensors are available for:

  • Total: Total cycles since installation
  • Daily: Cycles today (resets at midnight)
  • Yesterday: Cycles from yesterday
  • 2h: Cycles in the last 2 hours
  • 4h: Cycles in the last 4 hours
  • Monthly: Cycles this month

docs.title: Entity Names
docs.text:
Example entity names:

  • sensor.*_heating_cycling_total
  • sensor.*_heating_cycling_daily
  • sensor.*_heating_cycling_2h
  • sensor.*_hot_water_cycling_total
  • sensor.*_cooling_cycling_total
  • sensor.*_defrost_cycling_total

docs.title: Automatic Reset
docs.text:
• Daily sensors: Reset automatically at midnight
  • 2h and 4h sensors: Reset automatically every 2/4 hours
  • Monthly sensors: Reset at the beginning of each month

docs.title: Cycling Offsets
docs.text:
You can configure offsets to adjust cycle counts:

lambda_heat_pumps:
  cycling_offsets:
    heating: 0
    hot_water: 0
    cooling: 0
    defrost: 0

docs.title: Monitoring System Health
docs.text:
Track cycling patterns to identify issues:

  • Unusually high cycling may indicate problems
  • Compare daily cycles to detect changes
  • Monitor 2h/4h cycles for immediate feedback

docs.title: Energy Efficiency
docs.text:
Use cycling data to optimize energy usage:

  • Reduce unnecessary cycling
  • Optimize operating schedules
  • Identify peak usage times

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Energy Consumption Sensors
  • Features Overview

docs.title: Energy Consumption Sensors
docs.text: Energy consumption sensors track the energy usage of your heat pump by operating mode.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: These sensors provide detailed energy tracking for different operating modes, helping you understand your system's energy consumption patterns.

docs.title: By Operating Mode
docs.text:
• Heating Energy: Energy consumed during heating
  • Hot Water Energy: Energy consumed for hot water heating
  • Cooling Energy: Energy consumed during cooling
  • Defrost Energy: Energy consumed during defrosting

docs.title: Time Periods
docs.text:
For each operating mode, sensors track:

  • Total: Total energy since installation
  • Daily: Energy consumed today
  • Monthly: Energy consumed this month
  • Yearly: Energy consumed this year

docs.title: Entity Names
docs.text:
Example entity names:

  • sensor.*_heating_energy_consumption_total
  • sensor.*_heating_energy_consumption_daily
  • sensor.*_heating_energy_consumption_monthly
  • sensor.*_hot_water_energy_consumption_total

docs.title: Source Sensors
docs.text:
Configure source sensors for energy readings:

lambda_heat_pumps:
  energy_sensors:
    heating: sensor.heat_pump_power
    hot_water: sensor.heat_pump_power

docs.title: Unit Conversion
docs.text:
The integration automatically handles unit conversion:

  • Wh (Watt-hours)
  • kWh (Kilowatt-hours)
  • MWh (Megawatt-hours)

docs.title: Energy Monitoring
docs.text:
Track energy consumption over time:

  • Monitor daily energy usage
  • Compare monthly consumption
  • Track yearly totals

docs.title: Cost Analysis
docs.text:
Use energy data for cost calculations:

  • Calculate operating costs
  • Compare different time periods
  • Identify high-consumption periods

docs.title: Efficiency Analysis
docs.text:
Analyze system efficiency:

  • Compare energy consumption by mode
  • Identify optimization opportunities
  • Track efficiency improvements

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Cycling Sensors
  • Features Overview

docs.title: Features
docs.text: The Lambda Heat Pumps integration provides comprehensive monitoring and control of your Lambda heat pump system.

docs.title: Automatic Module Detection
docs.text:
The integration automatically detects available modules:

  • Heat pumps
  • Boilers
  • Buffers
  • Solar modules
  • Heating circuits

Based on detected hardware, appropriate entities are created automatically.

docs.title: Modbus/TCP Support
docs.text:
Full support for Lambda heat pumps via Modbus/TCP protocol:

  • Real-time data reading
  • Bidirectional communication
  • Register-based configuration
  • Error handling and retry logic

docs.title: Temperature Sensors
docs.text:
Monitor temperatures throughout your system:

  • Heat pump temperatures
  • Boiler temperatures
  • Buffer temperatures
  • Heating circuit temperatures
  • Hot water temperatures

docs.title: Cycling Sensors
docs.text:
Comprehensive cycling counters for all operating modes:

  • Heating cycles: Total, daily, yesterday, 2h, 4h, monthly
  • Hot water cycles: Total, daily, yesterday, 2h, 4h, monthly
  • Cooling cycles: Total, daily, yesterday, 2h, 4h, monthly
  • Defrost cycles: Total, daily, yesterday, 2h, 4h, monthly

All cycling sensors automatically reset at midnight.

docs.title: Energy Consumption Sensors
docs.text:
Detailed energy tracking by operating mode:

  • Heating energy consumption
  • Hot water energy consumption
  • Cooling energy consumption
  • Defrost energy consumption
  • Monthly and yearly totals

docs.title: Climate Control
docs.text:
Control your heating and hot water:

  • Set target temperatures
  • Monitor current temperatures
  • Adjust temperature ranges
  • Control heating circuits independently

docs.title: Heating Curve Configuration
docs.text:
Easy adjustment of heating curve parameters:

  • Cold point configuration (-22°C)
  • Mid point configuration (0°C)
  • Warm point configuration (+22°C)
  • Flow line offset adjustment (-10°C to +10°C)

See Heating Curve Guide for details.

docs.title: Room Thermostat Integration
docs.text:
External sensor integration for precise control:

  • Room temperature offset
  • Room temperature factor
  • Automatic flow temperature adjustment

docs.title: PV Surplus Control
docs.text:
Solar power integration:

  • Automatic PV surplus detection
  • Energy-optimized operation modes
  • Configurable thresholds

docs.title: Entity Naming
docs.text:
Flexible entity naming options:

  • Legacy Modbus names (compatible with older configurations)
  • Modern descriptive names
  • Custom prefixes

docs.title: Migration System
docs.text:
Automatic migration between versions:

  • Preserves entity configurations
  • Handles breaking changes
  • Maintains compatibility

docs.title: Debug Logging
docs.text:
Comprehensive logging for troubleshooting:

  • Modbus communication logs
  • Entity creation logs
  • Error tracking
  • Performance metrics

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Heating Curve Configuration
  • Cycling Sensors
  • Energy Consumption
  • Configuration Guide

docs.title: Heating Curve Configuration
docs.text: The heating curve configuration allows you to fine-tune how your heat pump responds to outside temperature changes.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The heating curve defines the relationship between outside temperature and flow temperature. The integration uses three support points to create a linear interpolation curve.

docs.title: Cold Point (-22°C)
docs.text: The flow temperature when the outside temperature is very cold (-22°C).

docs.title: Mid Point (0°C)
docs.text: The flow temperature at moderate outside temperatures (0°C).

docs.title: Warm Point (+22°C)
docs.text: The flow temperature when the outside temperature is warm (+22°C).

docs.title: Number Entities
docs.text:
For each heating circuit (HC1, HC2, etc.), the following Number entities are automatically created:

  • number.*_hc1_heating_curve_cold_outside_temp - Cold point at -22°C
  • number.*_hc1_heating_curve_mid_outside_temp - Mid point at 0°C
  • number.*_hc1_heating_curve_warm_outside_temp - Warm point at +22°C

docs.title: Flow Line Offset
docs.text:
The Flow Line Offset allows fine-tuning of the calculated heating curve flow temperature:

  • Range: -10.0°C to +10.0°C
  • Step Size: 0.1°C
  • Modbus Register: Register 50 (relative to the heating circuit's base address)
  • Bidirectional Synchronization: Reads current value from Modbus register and writes changes directly back

Example: If the calculated heating curve temperature is 35.0°C and you set an offset of +2.0°C, the actual flow temperature will be increased to 37.0°C.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings → Devices & Services
  2. Select your heating circuit (e.g., "HC1")
  3. Find the Number entities section
  4. Adjust the heating curve support points as needed
  5. Optionally adjust the flow line offset for fine-tuning

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Start with default values and adjust gradually
  • Monitor system performance after changes
  • Consider seasonal adjustments
  • Use the flow line offset for minor adjustments

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Configuration Guide
  • Features Overview

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide will help you install the Lambda Heat Pumps integration in Home Assistant.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Home Assistant installed and running
  • HACS (Home Assistant Community Store) installed
  • Lambda heat pump with Modbus/TCP interface
  • Network access to the Lambda controller

docs.title: Step 1: Install HACS
docs.text:
If you haven't installed HACS yet:

  1. Go to HACS Installation Guide
  2. Follow the instructions to install HACS
  3. Restart Home Assistant

docs.title: Step 2: Add Custom Repository
docs.text:
1. Open HACS in Home Assistant
  2. Go to Integrations
  3. Click the three dots menu (⋮) in the top right
  4. Select Custom repositories
  5. Add the repository:
  6. Repository: GuidoJeuken-6512/lambda_wp_hacs
  7. Category: Integration
  8. Click Add

docs.title: Step 3: Install Integration
docs.text:
1. Search for "Lambda Heat Pumps" in HACS
  2. Click on the integration
  3. Click Download
  4. Restart Home Assistant

docs.title: Manual Installation
docs.text:
If you prefer to install manually:

  1. Download the latest release from GitHub Releases
  2. Extract the ZIP file
  3. Copy the lambda_heat_pumps folder to your custom_components directory: 
    config/custom_components/lambda_heat_pumps/
  4. Restart Home Assistant

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
After installation, configure the integration:

  1. Go to Settings → Devices & Services
  2. Click Add Integration
  3. Search for "Lambda Heat Pumps"
  4. Enter your configuration:
  5. Name: A name for your installation (e.g., "EU08L")
  6. Host: IP address of your Lambda controller
  7. Port: Modbus TCP port (default: 502)
  8. Slave ID: Modbus Slave ID (default: 1)
  9. Firmware Version: Select your firmware version

docs.title: Finding Your Firmware Version
docs.text:
To find your Lambda controller's firmware version:

  1. From the main screen, click on the heat pump
  2. Click the "i" button on the left
  3. Click the button on the right that looks like a computer chip (last one)
  4. The firmware version will be displayed

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Configuration Guide - Learn about advanced configuration options
  • Features Overview - Discover all available features
  • Troubleshooting - Solve common issues
